Fig. 1 Bifunctional Zn complexes: salphen (salen type) [61], porphyrin [59] and N-SB. Fig 1 Scheme 1 Synthesis of bifunctional 4a-5b (Zn-N-SB+/X−) complexes. Scheme 1 Fig. 2 Halogen interaction with the zinc cation in 4a’-5b’ complexes. Fig 2 Fig. 3 H1-NMR spectra of complex 5a: Experimental (CD3CN, blue, middle) and theoretical DFT calculated (red) for 5a (top) iodine close to ammonium and 5a’ (bottom) iodine close to zinc structures. Fig 3 Fig. 4 VTNA: Variable time normalization analysis for bifunctional catalyst 5a. Reaction conditions: 30.2 mmol SO, 20 bar CO2, 100 °C, 6 h. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Proposed mechanism for the CO2 cycloaddition into styrene oxide using bifunctional catalyst 5a (its cationic moiety is represented by [Zn]+). Fig 5 Fig. 6 Proposed mechanism for the CO2 cycloaddition into styrene oxide using binary catalyst formed by neutral complex 1 and NBu4I. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Scope of the cyclic carbonate synthesis catalyzed by 5a. Reaction conditions: epoxide (30.2 mmol), catalyst 5a (0.06 mmol), 6 h. Bifunctional pyrrole containing nitrogen Schiff base zinc complexes were developed as single catalysts for the solvent free CO2 cycloaddition into epoxides. Four zwitterionic complexes (Zn-N-SB+/X−) were prepared by quaternarization of their neutral zinc precursor (Zn-N-SB) with different alkyl halides. The experimental compound characterization (NMR, IR, HRMS) was completed using the density functional theory (DFT) to obtain optimized structures. All the bifunctional zinc complexes efficiently promoted the solvent free cycloaddition of CO2 into styrene oxide, acting as both, Lewis acid and Lewis base catalyst, to form styrene cyclic carbonate in very good yields (up to 90 %) reaching TOF values up to 257 h−1. Best catalytic activity was noted for the iodine containing zwitterionic species (Zn-N-SB+/I−) that was used in very small loading (0.2 mol%) to enlarge the reaction scope to other epoxides in solvent free conditions, allowing high cyclic carbonate yields in the case of terminal epoxides. The comparison of the catalytic system formed by the neutral zinc complex (Zn-N-SB) combined to an iodine ammonium salt and its derived zwitterionic iodine containing complex (Zn-N-SB+/I−), showed that the bifunctional catalyst is more active. In order to get mechanistic insights, for both catalytic systems, the reaction order was calculated by VTNA (variable time normalization analysis) and the epoxide opening regioselectivity was determined using aniline as nucleophile. Graphical abstract Zinc zwitterionic complex as bifunctional catalyst for the CO2 cycloaddition into epoxides Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 Bifunctional catalysts Styrene epoxide Schiff bases Zinc complexes DFT calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction As carbon dioxide largely contributes to greenhouse effect, many efforts have been made in the last decades to develop new ways to use it [1] to produce methane and oxygenated fuels [2]. Nevertheless, CO2 can also be used as a C1 building-block to obtain valuable products such as carboxylic acids, carbamates, urea [3] and organic carbonates, in particular cyclic carbonates that can be prepared from the CO2 cycloaddition into epoxides in a 100 % atom efficient reaction [4,5]. In this catalytic process, the cooperation between a Lewis acid (which coordinates to the oxygen atom of the epoxide) and a Lewis base (able to open the epoxide and act as a good leaving group), is crucial to selectively obtain the cyclic carbonate (thermodynamic product) instead of polycarbonate (kinetic product) [6]. As simple ammonium halides (NBu4X) can be used as Lewis base catalysts for this purpose, many studies focused on the development of Lewis acid catalysts, such as organocatalysts [7–13], ionic liquids [14–17], heterogeneous MOFs [18–28], graphene oxides [29,30], polymers [31–38] or silicas [39–45]. Homogeneous catalysts containing a Lewis acid cation were also developed, mainly Al [46–50] or Cr [51] complexes, although nontoxic Zn species are quite interesting since they are stable to oxidation, and selective towards cyclic carbonates [52–58]. In the last decade, complexes bearing both, Lewis acid and basic sites were reported as bifunctional catalysts for the CO2 insertion to epoxides, and in particular zinc complexes having porphyrin [59,60] or salen [61,62] ligands (Fig. 1 ). We developed a series of aniline derived nitrogen Schiff base (N-SB) complexes [63–65] that combines the nitrogen coordination sphere of porphyrins to the flexibility of salen ligands. The corresponding zinc complexes [63–65] proved to be robust and efficient catalysts combined to tetrabutyl ammonium halides (TBAX) and other groups reported similar zinc species with pyridine or phenantroline containing tetra-aza donor ligands [52–58]. Despite good activities in presence of a slight excess of TBAX (molar ratio: 1.5 to 5 vs. Zn) the Lewis acid zinc complexes are not efficient catalysts for the CO2 cycloaddition into epoxides. In order to avoid the use of TBAX, we now incorporated the halogen and ammonium functions into the Zn-N-SB species, thus leading to bifunctional zwitterionic catalysts. Herein we describe the synthesis and characterization of a series of novel bifunctional pyrrole-Schiff base zinc complexes, (Zn-N-SB+/X−). The experimental data were compared with those obtained by computational calculations using Density Functional Theory (DFT), regarding bond energies and NMR spectra of optimized structures, giving interesting insights of their reactivity. Then, we evaluated the catalytic properties of the (Zn-N-SB+/X−) zwitterionic complexes as single bifunctional (Lewis acid and base) catalyst for the solvent free cycloaddition of CO2 into epoxides to form cyclic organic carbonates, and compared them with their corresponding two components Lewis acid (Zn-N-SB) and Lewis base (TBAX) system. Finally, to get mechanistic insights, we determined the epoxide opening regioselectivity and the reaction order using the variable time normalization analysis (VTNA) for both catalytic systems. Results and discussion Synthesis of zwitterionic Schiff base zinc complexes The bifunctional pyrrole-Schiff base zinc complexes were synthetized by the quaternarization of 1, a neutral nitrogen Schiff base zinc complex that was recently developed in our group [66]. As this precursor contains a central amine group in its ligand, the reaction with alkyl halides (RX) may lead to the formation of corresponding zwitterionic species (Zn-N-SB+/X−) 4a, 4b, 5a and 5b. According to literature [67], the use of alkyl bromide and iodide reactants allows the quaternarization whereas no reaction takes place when using alkyl chlorides; their lower reactivity may be due to the worse behaviour of Cl as leaving group, compared to Br or I. The amine quaternarization reactions of the zinc precursor were carried out in refluxing THF using an excess of benzyl bromide (2a), 1-bromopropane (2b), 1-iodopropane (3a) and 1-iodobutane (3b) respectively (Scheme 1 ). Iodine containing complexes 5a and 5b yields were improved by decreasing alkyl iodide amounts and replacing THF by acetone, allowing their direct precipitation. Spectral analysis was made by ATR-FTIR (Fig. S1 in Supplementary Information) and NMR spectra could be recorded in deuterated acetonitrile (Figs. S2–S8). As the prepared zwitterionic (Zn-N-SB+/X−) complexes are almost insoluble in common organic solvents, all the attempts to get suitable crystals for XRay studies were unsuccessful, due to the zwitterionic nature of the complexes which are soluble in both polar and apolar solvents. Their characterization was then completed by High Resolution Mass Spectra (HRMS) within a very soft ionization mode (CSI: Cold-Spray Ionization) (Figs. S9–S12) leading to the exact masses of the cations (Zn-N-SB+), without considering the halides. Theoretical calculations of zwitterionic complexes As no XRay analysis could be done, we used theoretical calculations to confirm the structures of the zwitterionic complexes, since this approach was successful to determine the zinc coordination mode for other zinc complexes [55,68]. The bifunctional pyrrole-Schiff base zinc complexes calculations have been carried out at PBE/TZP level of theory with ZORA correction (see Computational details section). The geometry of each of the four prepared complexes was optimized by placing the halogen atom either on the central amine group for 4a, 4b, 5a and 5b structures (as in Scheme 1) or on the zinc atom side for 4a’, 4b’, 5a’ and 5b’ structures (Fig. 2 ). In this second set of complexes a fifth coordination of the zinc center may occur with the halogen anion. The calculated bond energies, reported in Table 1 , show that in general, the structures in which the halogen is closer to the ammonium are slightly more stable than their corresponding analogs having a halogen near the zinc center, except for complex 4b’in which the bromine coordination to the zinc led to a more stable structure than 4b. The difference of energies being quite low (∼ 2.6 kcal/mol) it suggests that the iodine or bromine atoms can quasi-freely rotate around the structure of the complex. In order to establish the geometry of one of the bifunctional iodine complex Zn-N-SB+/I−, we compared the theoretical and experimental data for both structures: iodine closer to the ammonium (5a) or to the zinc (5a’). Tables 2 and 3 give some calculated bond lengths and angles for 5a and 5a’structures respectively and in both cases the coordination of the zinc with the central N atom of the triamine ligand does not occur in the zwitterionic species, even if it was described for their precursor complex 1 [66]. In fact, the distance between the zinc and the central ammonium N16 is too long (4.80 Å for 5a and 5.59 for 5a’). Concerning 5a structure (Table 2) the zinc is well tetra-coordinated to the other nitrogen atoms and the amine N atoms (N5 and N23) are slightly closer (∼0.1 Å) than those of the imines (N2, N20). Besides, quite sharper N-Zn-N angles (∼84.3°) are observed between the N atoms along the same ligand moieties (N2-Zn-N5 or N20-Zn-N23) than those on different sides of the ligands (112.89°-130°). Thus, the zinc adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry in structure 5a. Finally, it can be seen that the ammonium cation N16 is quite far from the bulky iodine anion (4.04 Å). This may confirm that the iodine is quite free to move around the complex, as suggested regarding the energy results of Table 1. In the case of the structure 5a’ (Table 3) the iodine clearly interacts with the zinc center (distance Zn-I= 2.56 Å) but the penta-coordination does not occur, since one of the N atoms moved away, the Zn-N2 distance being of 4.58 Å. This decoordination is confirmed by the unusual angle values for N2-Zn-N5 and N2-Zn-N23. Nevertheless, the other N5, N20 and N23 atoms are still linked to the metal (∼2.06 Å) and larger angle values are noticed for N5-Zn-N20 and N5-Zn-N23 (∼116.41°) than for N20-Zn-N23 (81.29°). Thus, in the 5a’ structure, the geometry around the zinc center is also a distorted tetrahedron. Similar observations have been made for the other zwitterionic complexes considering both optimized structures (4a/4a’ 4b/4b’ and 5b/5b’: see Tables S1–S3). In all cases, the zinc has a tera-coordinated sphere, by means of either four N atoms in 4a-5b series, or by means of the halogen and three N atoms 4a’-5b’ series. A comparative study between experimental and theoretical proton and carbon NMR data for the iodine and n-propyl containing complex Zn-N-SB+/I− was realized, considering the two possible structures: 5a, with iodine close to the ammonium and 5a’ where the iodine is closer to the zinc (Fig. 3 ). The two-corresponding theoretical H1-NMR spectra obtained using DFT calculations (Fig. 3, top and bottom), only shows eleven different proton resonances due to the molecule C2-symmetry. The experimental spectrum recorded in CD3CN at room temperature (Fig. 3, middle) shows almost the same chemical shift as in the theoretical ones, concerning the low-field CH close to the imine, H3 (8.18–8.3 ppm) stating that the N2 of the imine remains coordinated to the zinc center. Similar chemical shifts are also observed in the three spectra for the pyrrole protons H6, H7, and H8 (6.3 – 7.6 ppm) but also for the up-field propyl ending protons H11 and H12 (2 – 0.9 ppm). In the experimental spectra the coupling with neighbor protons lead to a multiplet for H12 and a broad pic for H11, but integration data confirms they are CH3 and CH2 groups respectively. Another common point is that the central ammonium N16 is not coordinated to the zinc center, since this may form a six-membered cycle with the aliphatic protons, thus diastereotopic signals may be observed for H13, H14, H15 protons, as already described for complex 1 [66]. Therefore, no splitting of the aliphatic protons is noticed in any of the three spectra, and it also confirms that the iodine is not linked to the zinc in 5a’ structure, according with the distance data on Table 3. Besides, the large signals for aliphatic protons observed in the experimental spectrum, as well as the overlap of H14 and H15 in one broad signal (∼3.2 ppm) are far from the sharp signals expected when the zinc has a fifth coordination site. The main differences in the theoretical 1H NMR spectra concern the protons which are closer to the ammonium cation: H9 from the methyl group in 5a structure (∼4.6 ppm) up shields in 5a’ spectrum (∼3.1 ppm) which is closer to the experimental chemical shift (2.88 ppm). On the contrary, the H10 from the CH2 of the propyl group goes down shield from 5a to 5a’ calculated spectra, and the experimental chemical shift (∼3.1 ppm) suits more likely with the one of the 5a structure. This comparison shows that in NMR conditions, the complex adopts a structure showing similar proton resonances with both proposed structures, thus suggesting that there is an equilibrium, in which the large iodine anion remains close to the methyl linked to the ammonium, but far from the propyl group, mainly due to steric hindrance. The experimental and theoretical 13C NMR spectra were also compared (Fig. S6) and the signals obtained for the 5a structure (iodine closer to the ammonium) are similar to the experimental ones. The comparisons of the experimental and the DFT calculated 1H and 13C- NMR spectra were also carried out for both structures of complex 4a (Fig. S4-A and -B) and 4a’ (Fig. S5-A and B) and the same trends were observed than for 5a and 5a’, pointing out the halide mobility around the cationic complex. Catalytic activity As each of the four above prepared zwitterionic zinc complexes (Zn-N-SB+/X−) combines a Lewis acid (zinc cation) and a Lewis base (ammonium halide) moieties in their structure, they may behave as bifunctional catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 into epoxides. The catalytic activity of 4a, 4b, 5a and 5b was tested using styrene oxide as model epoxide and very small catalytic amounts (0.2 mol% vs. epoxide) under solvent-free conditions at 100 °C in a steel reactor to control the amount of introduced gas (initial CO2 pressure of 20 bar). The reaction media were analyzed by 1H NMR using an internal standard, leading styrene oxide (SO) conversion and cyclic styrene carbonate (SC) yield (Table 4 ). As neutral complex 1 was used to synthesize these bifunctional complexes, the catalytic systems combining 1 and tetrabutylammonium halides (TBAX) were also evaluated for comparison. As expected, zinc complex 1 has no significant catalytic activity alone (entry 1), while ammonium halides (TBAX) have moderate catalytic activity (entries 2 and 4), but combining both (in equimolar ratios) clearly improved the cyclic styrene carbonate yields (entries 3 and 5). When testing the catalytic activity of the bifunctional complexes (Zn-N-SB+/X−) no TBAX was added in the solvent free reaction. The bromine zwitterionic species 4a and 4b gave lower styrene oxide conversions (12 and 28 %, entries 6 and 7) than their corresponding two component system (56 % for entry 3). Besides, complex 4a synthesized from benzyl bromide, has poor catalytic activity (5 % yield of cyclic carbonate was formed), probably because bromide is less accessible due to a bulky ammonium cation, as it appears on the structures. Much better results were obtained with iodine zwitterionic species 5a and 5b (entries 8 and 9) leading the selective CO2 cycloaddition into styrene oxide in high yields (84–90 %). The halogen anion effect can be observed by comparing the catalytic activity of 4b and 5a complexes for which the cyclic carbonate yield improves from 25 % to 90 % (entries 7 and 9) when replacing Br by I, because the iodine anion is more available. This availability may be due to the larger size of iodine that reduces its interaction with the ammonium cation, thus facilitating the epoxide ring opening. Besides iodine is a good leaving group, which is crucial to favour the cyclization step of the reaction. This point may also explain why bifunctional catalysts (Zn-N-SB+/X−) are more active than their corresponding two-component (Zn-N-SB+TBAI) catalytic system when X=I (entries 8 and 9 vs. 5) whereas disappointing results are obtained for X=Br (entries 6 and 7 vs. 3). In order to get softer reaction conditions, temperature was reduced but the catalytic activity dropped (entry 10). When reducing pressure to 2 and 1 bar of CO2 and thus lowering the styrene oxide amount, a good cyclic carbonate yield was obtained (entry 11). Even if the TOF value decreased during this test, it showed that the reaction can occur without high pressures. Similar values were obtained when bubbling CO2; However, using a reactor is important to control the CO2 amount, avoiding its bubbling and gas waste in open vessels. Finally, and optimization of the reaction parameters at 20 bar of CO2 using the bifunctional catalyst 5a allowed to improve the TOF to 257 h−1 by increasing the temperature and reducing the reaction time as well as the catalyst amount to 0.1% mol. (entry 12). Kinetics study As 5a proved its activity for styrene carbonate synthesis via CO2 cycloaddition, the kinetics of the reaction was studied in order to elucidate the order for the catalyst, as already reported for a different bifunctional catalyst based on Zn [54]. Due to the inability to perform in situ measurements or consecutive sampling, the progress of the reaction was measured by independent reactions. Due to this fact, VTNA (Variable Time Normalization Analysis) [69–71] was chosen as method to elucidate the order in catalyst as it allows the comparison of progress profiles with different catalyst concentrations by means of the t [cat]n adjustment. To do so, various catalytic test were carried out under different reaction times, using two catalyst concentrations (each point correspond to a test). Then the styrene carbonate yields versus t [cat]n was plotted using different n order values (0, 0.5, 1, 1.5 and 2). Therefore, the order in catalyst correspond to the n value for which both profiles overlap. Fig. 4 shows the two progress reaction profiles with different concentrations of 5a (0.00858 M and 0.0171 M) under the same conditions. The normalization was carried out by multiplying the abscissae by the catalyst concentration in each profile raised to the power of n, where n = 0.5, 1, 1.5 and 2 (Fig. 4). It is observed that both profiles overlap when n=1, pointing out that the reaction is first-order with respect to zinc catalyst 5a, and therefore, only one molecule of the complex is involved in the catalytic cycle. Furthermore, the bifunctional catalyst 5a was evaluated along with a Lewis base such as NBu4I (0.2 mol% vs. SO) in a molar ratio Zn/I = 1/3, providing significantly lower yield of styrene cyclic carbonate than when using complex 5a as single catalyst (66% vs. 90 %). To compare this bifunctional catalysts 5a with the binary system formed by neutral complex 1 and NBu4I, the order of reaction for each component (Lewis acid and Lewis base) was determined by variable time normalization analysis (VTNA). The reaction order for the Lewis base was determined by plotting two kinetic profiles at different concentrations ( [NBu4I] = 0.00858 M and 0.01715 M) and using a constant Lewis acid concentration ([1] = 0.00858 M). As the two profiles overlap when n =1 (Fig. S13) the reaction has a first order in NBu4I catalyst. Next, the reaction order for the neutral zinc complex 1 (Lewis acid) was determined, in the same way, by plotting two kinetic profiles at different concentrations ([1] = 0.00858 M and 0.01715 M) keeping NBu4I concentration constant ( [NBu4I] = 0.00858 M). As the profiles overlap for n=0.5 (Fig. S14) the reaction order with respect to Zn is less than one, which suggests that not all of the complex amount is an active form. This fact agrees with our previous study [66], in which it was shown that when complex 1 is dissolved in a low coordination medium, it undergoes an equilibrium between a zinc tetra or pentacoordinate forms, where the fifth coordination site is the N atom of the central amine of the N-SB base ligand. Ring opening regioselectivity In order to determine the regioselectivity of epoxide opening, the addition of aniline to styrene oxide was investigated under conditions similar to those used for the CO2 cycloaddition. Two amino alcohols were formed by opening the epoxide on α or β positions and easily quantified by 1H NMR analysis (Table 5 ). Thus, the most favored position for the nucleophilic attack, and therefore the opening of the styrene oxide, was estimated without any catalyst (entry 1) and in the presence of zwitterionic zinc complex 5a (entry 2) or its neutral zinc precursor 1, the latter combined to NBu4I (entry 3). In all cases, the conversion of the styrene oxide was complete forming amino alcohols in ∼ 77 % yield. In the absence of catalyst, the alpha position is more susceptible to nucleophilic attack (α/β = 67/33), due to electronic effects although it is more hindered [72]. When the 5a complex is used as a catalyst, the α position is still the most favored but the difference between alpha and beta is smaller (α/β = 58/42) than in the absence of catalyst. As for 5a, the binary catalytic system formed by complex 1 and NBu4I in a 1/1 molar ratio favored the α position but the difference was smaller (α/β = 55/45). The loss of regioselectivity could be explained by the decrease of the activation energy and thus, the coordination of the epoxide to the Zn(II) complex could facilitate the ring opening in both alpha and beta positions [73]. Proposed mechanisms Regarding the results described herein concerning the reaction order of the zinc 5a and 1 catalysts, and those of the epoxide ring opening regioselectivity, along with previous reports on other Lewis acid complexes [74–76], we propose a mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO2 to styrene oxide. In the presence of the bifunctional and zwitterionic catalyst 5a, the mechanism has four main steps (Fig. 5 ), beginning with the coordination of the Zn cation to the oxygen of the epoxide. Then, the iodide atom on the bifunctional catalyst 5a acts as a nucleophile opening the epoxide ring. Even if this nucleophilic addition can take place on both α or β carbons of the epoxide ring, the alpha position may be slightly favored (entry 2, Table 4) because of the steric hindrance of the bulky complex 5a, that is closer to the β carbon. In the third and next step, the insertion of CO2 occurs into the Zn-O bond. Finally, the oxygen atom bonded to Zn attacks the carbon on α position, assisted by the iodine good leaving group, thus closing the cyclic carbonate. In the same step, the zinc / iodide complex 5a is restored. We also propose a mechanism for the binary catalytic system formed by neutral zinc complex 1 and NBu4I in a 1:1 molar ratio (Fig. 6 ). As the reaction order for complex 1 was determined to be less than one using VTAN (Fig. S14), there may be an equilibrium between a five and a four coordinated zinc species (Fig. 6). In the pentacoordinate form (N5), the central amine completes the coordination sphere, while in the tetracoordinate form (N4), the oxygen atom of styrene oxide can form a bond with the Zn center. Then, the nucleophilic attack by the iodide is favored, leading to the opening of the epoxide cycle and CO2 inserts between the oxygen and the Zn. Finally, the ring closure provides the cyclic styrene carbonate, and releases both catalytic components, iodide and neutral complex 1. Reaction scope In order to complete the catalytic activity study of complex 5a, various epoxides were used as substrates. Five epoxides were tested and compared to styrene oxide that gives product A. All the conversions and carbonate yields (Fig. 7 ), were determined by 1H NMR analysis using an internal standard (mesitylene). As seen in previous work, the CO2 insertion into non terminal epoxides, such as cyclohexene oxide is largely more difficult than in external epoxides [77] and no significant amount of carbonate I was detected using the zinc bifunctional catalyst 5a. The reaction scope was more successful with terminal epoxides, and those containing short alkyl chains led to very high yields (>93 %) of the corresponding carbonates B and C. However, the cyclic product F yield significantly decreased with a longer n-butyl chain on the epoxide, and it may be related to the low solubility of the zwitterionic catalyst 5a in non-polar epoxides. Thus, epoxides containing polar groups such as Cl or O atoms were examined. In the case of chlorinated epoxides, good results were obtained for a styrene oxide derivative (product D), while disappointing epichlorohydrin conversion and corresponding product E were noticed. Cyclic carbonates G and H were obtained in excellent yields from epoxides containing oxygenated substituents, glycidol, afforded the best results of all the tested epoxides, with almost complete conversion and 98 % yield of the cyclic product H. The excellent reactivity of glycidol which is derived from bio-based glycerol, may also rely on the formation of an hydrogen bond with the oxygen atom of the epoxide, thus facilitating the ring opening by the Lewis base [78]. Even if the nature of the epoxide can affect the cyclic carbonate formation, the solubility of the catalyst in these substrates remains a crucial point for solvent free reactions. Hydrogen bond donor groups may thus facilitate the zwitterionic catalyst 5a solubility. The addition of an organic solvent in which the catalyst and CO2 are highly soluble may improve its cycloaddition to a large variety of epoxides, as we already described using CH2Cl2 and the binary catalytic system complex 1 and ammonium halide [66]. Conclusions A series of bifunctional (Zn-N-SB+/X−) complexes 4a-b and 5a-b were synthesized by quaternization of the central amine of the neutral zinc precursor (Zn-N-SB) complex 1. The experimental characterization of the zwitterionic species was confirmed by the analysis of theoretical NMR spectra and DFT calculations, pointing out that the zinc center, is not coordinated neither to the iodine nor to the ammonium, and under NMR conditions. The large iodine anion remains close to the methyl but far from the propyl group, mainly due to steric hindrance. Besides, the quasi-free rotation of the halide around the structure, was confirmed by the bond energies values small gap. This iodine mobility may be positive for the bifunctional catalytic activity of these zwitterionic complex, as the halogen (Lewis base) has to be near the epoxide to open it. In fact, in the first reaction step, the epoxide coordinates to the zinc cation (Lewis acid) through the oxygen atom of the epoxide. Each of the prepared zwitterionic complexes showed catalytic activity for the CO2 cycloaddition to styrene oxide under solvent-free conditions. Among other bifunctional complexes that have been described and tested under same conditions for the CO2 cycloaddition to styrene oxide, catalyst 5a lead 257 h−1 TOF which is higher than for other Zn salen-type complexes, but remains little lower compared to a Zn metalloporphyrin [59]. The influence of the nature of the ammonium halide was demonstrated, the iodide containing catalysts being much more active than their bromide analogs. Besides, the propyl chain of the alkyl halides provided best performances: 5a (X = I, R = Pr) > 5b (X = I, R = Bu) > 4b (X = Br, R = Pr) > 4a (X = Br, R = Bn). Both bifunctional (Zn-N-SB+/I−) catalysts have better activities (84–90 % yield) than their corresponding two-component (Zn-N-SB+TBAI) catalytic system (75 % yield), but this trend is not observed when X=Br leading to disappointing results. The reaction scope with various epoxides revealed the new bifunctional catalyst 5a is active for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from terminal epoxides, especially those with electron donating groups. The importance of the solubility of 5a in the starting epoxides should be emphasized because the reaction is carried out without solvent. A kinetic approach using VTNA calculations showed a first order reaction for the bifunctional catalyst 5a, while it was found to be 0.5 for neutral catalyst 1 and first order in NBu4I catalyst. The study of the regioselectivity of styrene oxide opening with aniline concluded that the α position is little more favored. A reaction mechanism was proposed each catalytic systems: the bifunctional (Zn-N-SB+/I−) or the two-component system (Zn-N-SB + TBAI). The catalytic activity enhancement for iodine zwitterionic complexes 5a or 5b may rely on the larger size of iodine anion, facilitating the epoxide ring opening but also on its good leaving group activity that favors the final cyclization step, releasing the cyclic carbonate product. This point was thoroughly examined in a complementary computational study, out of the scope of this paper, and published very recently [73]. Experimental section General considerations All chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich® and used as received, in particular Et2Zn as 1.0 M solution in hexane, styrene oxide (97 %) and anhydrous solvents in Sure/Seal ™ bottles. Other solvents were purchased from Across and used without further purification. Carbon dioxide (99.995 % purity) was supplied by Air Liquide. 1H (relaxation delay = 1 s, T = 25 °C), 13C (relaxation delay = 2 s, T = 25 °C) and HSQC (relaxation delay = 2 s, T = 25 °C) NMR spectra were acquired on a Bruker Ascend™ 400 spectrometer in order to characterize complexes and determine conversions and yields in catalytic tests. All spectra were acquired at ambient temperature and referenced to the solvent signals [79]. Samples were prepared in CDCl3, acetonitrile-d3, acetone-d6 and DMSO-d6. Infrared spectroscopy analysis was performed with a transformed Fourier-transformed IR spectrometer model NEXUS (Nicolet-Thermofisher, UK). Neat samples spectra were recorded in Attenuated Total Reflectance (ATR) mode with a Thunderdome (Spectratech) accessory containing Germanium crystal with a mono reflection at 45 deg. A Deuterated TriGlycine Sulfate (DTGS) detector was employed, with a 4 cm−1 resolution and apodisation Happ-Genzel and 256 scans. Mass spectrometry analysis was performed at CCSM-ICBMS in University Lyon1. The ionization method employed for zwitterionic complexes 4 and 5 was Cold-Spray ionization, which is a softer technique than ESI. As positive mode was also used, the observed exact masses corresponded to the cation, i.e., complexes containing the ammonium but without considering the halide (anion). Commercial alkyl halides 2 and 3 were used as received and neutral complex 1 was synthetized according previous work [66]. Synthesis of complexes 4a. To a solution of complex 1 (200 mg, 0.55 mmol) in THF (30 mL), benzyl bromide 2a (1.3 mL, 11.3 mmol, 20eq.) was added. The mixture was heated at 70 °C and stirred for 16 h. Catalytic tests All catalytic tests were performed in a 40 mL stainless steel reactor equipped with a thermocouple and stirred on a heating plate using a magnetic bar. CO2 cycloaddition: In a typical reaction, 0.06 mmol of bifunctional complex and styrene oxide (3.5 mL, 30.2 mmol) were placed into the reactor. The CO2 pressure had to be 20 bar so as to obtain an excess of CO2 with respect to SO. The reactor was heated to the desired temperature during the selected reaction time. Then, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature in an ice bath and depressurized slowly in the hood. When the experiment was completed, mesitylene (240 mg, 2 mmol) as internal standard was added with the help of 5 mL of CH2Cl2. The reaction mixture was then analyzed by NMR (200 µL of sample diluted in 800 µL of CDCl3). Styrene oxide opening by aniline: In a typical reaction, 0.06 mmol of catalyst, styrene oxide (3.5 mL, 30.2 mmol) and aniline (3.85 g, 41.3 mmol) were placed into the reactor. The reactor was heated to the desired temperature during the selected reaction time. Then, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature in an ice bath and depressurized slowly in the hood. When the experiment was completed, mesitylene (240 mg, 2 mmol) as internal standard was added with the help of 15 mL of CH2Cl2 and the mixture was stirred until homogenization. The reaction mixture was then analyzed by NMR (200 µL of sample diluted in 800 µL of CDCl3). DFT calculations Amsterdam Density Functional (ADF) program [81,82] (2014 and 2016 releases) developed by Baerends et al. was used to perform the DFT calculations [83–85]. Electron correlation was treated within a generalized gradient approximation (GGA) using the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [86]. This widely used functional of the GGA family has been herein used for the calculations of the thermodynamics properties, with a Triple Zeta plus Polarization (TZP) basis set, and with small frozen cores. Relativistic corrections were taken into account using the relativistic scalar zero-order regular approximation (ZORA) formalism. [87] This functional has been validated by a large number of studies and calculations, like Mardirossian and Head-Gordon paper (200 exchange-correlation functionals) [88], and studies of tin complexes [89–91]. Harmonic vibrational frequency calculations have been performed to confirm the nature of all stationary points. Therefore, all calculated frequencies are real for reagents and products structures, while transition states structures are associated with one imaginary frequency. The energy convergence and the gradient convergence criteria were set to 1 e -4 a.u. and 2 e-4 a.u., respectively. coredata.dc:description: Bifunctional pyrrole containing nitrogen Schiff base zinc complexes were developed as single catalysts for the solvent free CO2 cycloaddition into epoxides. Four zwitterionic complexes (Zn-N-SB+/X−) were prepared by quaternarization of their neutral zinc precursor (Zn-N-SB) with different alkyl halides. The experimental compound characterization (NMR, IR, HRMS) was completed using the density functional theory (DFT) to obtain optimized structures. All the bifunctional zinc complexes efficiently promoted the solvent free cycloaddition of CO2 into styrene oxide, acting as both, Lewis acid and Lewis base catalyst, to form styrene cyclic carbonate in very good yields (up to 90 %) reaching TOF values up to 257 h−1. Best catalytic activity was noted for the iodine containing zwitterionic species (Zn-N-SB+/I−) that was used in very small loading (0.2 mol%) to enlarge the reaction scope to other epoxides in solvent free conditions, allowing high cyclic carbonate yields in the case of terminal epoxides. The comparison of the catalytic system formed by the neutral zinc complex (Zn-N-SB) combined to an iodine ammonium salt and its derived zwitterionic iodine containing complex (Zn-N-SB+/I−), showed that the bifunctional catalyst is more active. In order to get mechanistic insights, for both catalytic systems, the reaction order was calculated by VTNA (variable time normalization analysis) and the epoxide opening regioselectivity was determined using aniline as nucleophile.
coredata.dc:title: Zwitterionic bifunctional stable zinc complexes as single catalysts for the valorization of CO2 into cyclic carbonates
